message: I'm pretty new at deploying Django
I'm using Apache+mod_wsgi, and I just switched to daemon mode (instead of embedded)
but I'm not sure what to set in WSGIDaemonProcess (process and thread count)
for the last application where we were using mod_wsgi, we weren't sure our app code was threadsafe, so we used threads=1.
(at the least you'd want as many as the machine has CPU cores, i suppose.)
at that point, the number of processes is the number of simultaneous requests you can handle, so i think you want to use as many as can fit in memory on the machine.
usually if it's a small VPS instance I set it to 5 processes, it works fine with relatively large number of pageviews
more processes - better concurrent request handling
on larger 2 CPU blades I'm running it with 16 processes, works fine again
using it with threads made it unstable in my experience (testing with siege)
@Vasil What's a "Small" VPS instance for you? I'm currently running on SliceHost's 1GB Ram slice.
mmm, I had 512mb in mind. We ran 2 apps with 5 processes each + solr + postgresql + memcache on a 1GB Rackspace instance, and that's about all it could handle.

you can easily experiment what works best, if you have a 4 core machine, run a 1GB VM instance on your workstation and hit it with siege or something similar and see how different confs will handle the load.
But 5 processes will work just fine for start, you could use the rest of RAM for memcache, tuning your DB or varnish
What does tweaking the number of threads do?

@diafygi Essentially, increases concurrency without the memory implications of multiprocess. You need your underlying libraries to be threadsafe, though (often not the case with C extensions). As ever, the excellent and under-read mod_wsgi docs have lots of information.
